docs.snippet: Ed Jucker, who coached the University of Cincinnati basketball team to three consecutive N.C.A.A. tournament finals and won the first two, died Saturday at his home on Callawassie Island, S.C., near Hilton Head Island.    He was 85 and had prostat...
docs.lead_paragraph: Ed Jucker, who coached the University of Cincinnati basketball team to three consecutive N.C.A.A. tournament finals and won the first two, died Saturday at his home on Callawassie Island, S.C., near Hilton Head Island. He was 85 and had prostate cancer, his wife, Joanne, said.
docs.abstract: Ed Jucker, who coached University of Cincinnati basketball team to three consecutive NCAA tournament finals and won first two, dies at 85; photo (M)

headline.main: Ed Jucker, 85, Who Coached Cincinnati to Basketball Titles

docs.snippet: WELL, we survived it, the W.E.F. Smackdown that held New York in its grip for the better part of a week.    The spin from the paid boosters is that we are all in a state of civic grace because thousands of participants in the World Economic Forum ...
docs.lead_paragraph: WELL, we survived it, the W.E.F. Smackdown that held New York in its grip for the better part of a week. The spin from the paid boosters is that we are all in a state of civic grace because thousands of participants in the World Economic Forum chose to do their networking among us.
docs.abstract: Clyde Haberman comments on how smoothly World Economic Forum went in New York (M)

headline.main: A Tough City, Surprised by Affection

docs.snippet: As in any kind of campaign that involves hustling for votes, the race for Academy Awards has its own rules, built up over many years, to protect the process from taint by forbidding gift giving, wining and dining and outright bribery.    But just ...
docs.lead_paragraph: As in any kind of campaign that involves hustling for votes, the race for Academy Awards has its own rules, built up over many years, to protect the process from taint by forbidding gift giving, wining and dining and outright bribery. But just as in politics, a fine art has developed for maneuvering the wiggle room in regulations, in this case those found in 21 paragraphs issued by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, which govern everything from pre-Oscar parties to the distribution of videotapes to the 6,000 voters.
docs.abstract: Article on ways that have been found to circumvent rules and regulations governing Academy Award voting, which cover everything from pre-Oscar parties to distribution of videotapes to voters (M)

headline.main: Ferreting Out The Loopholes In Oscar Rules

docs.snippet: It was 1980 and the patient in Dr. Glen Gabbard's consulting room had a pressing request.    She had just seen ''Ordinary People,'' she told him, and in the movie, Judd Hirsch, who played the therapist, hugged Timothy Hutton, who played the suicid...
docs.lead_paragraph: It was 1980 and the patient in Dr. Glen Gabbard's consulting room had a pressing request. She had just seen ''Ordinary People,'' she told him, and in the movie, Judd Hirsch, who played the therapist, hugged Timothy Hutton, who played the suicidal patient.
docs.abstract: Interview with Dr Glen Gabbard, psychoanalyst and author, who offers his views on how movies usually deal with mental illness; discusses A Beautiful Mind, new movie directed by Ron Howard chronicling life of mathematician John Forbes Nash Jr, schizophrenic who won 1994 Nobel Prize for economics; photos (L)

headline.main: A Rare Day: The Movies Get Mental Illness Right

docs.snippet: Dawid Olivier, a poet, longs so for houseflies that he's trembling, and he reckons there's not one to be had in all of gray, gloomy London. Flies seemed at best a bane back in South Africa.    But as portrayed by John Glover with the twanging inte...
docs.lead_paragraph: Dawid Olivier, a poet, longs so for houseflies that he's trembling, and he reckons there's not one to be had in all of gray, gloomy London. Flies seemed at best a bane back in South Africa. But as portrayed by John Glover with the twanging intensity of a soundly struck tuning fork, Dawid now recalls finding an inspirational meter as he swatted those flies, one after another, their corpses piling up. ''Whack! Whack! Whack!'' He says the words fiercely, but he might as well be singing the most sentimental of ballads.
docs.abstract: Ben Brantley reviews play Sorrows and Rejoicings, written and directed by Athol Fugard; Judith Light and Charlayne Woodard star; photo (M)

headline.main: A Dead Man's Failed Muse and Lost Women

docs.snippet: The road to the dream this year was glazed with ice. But inside the Holiday Inn ballroom's makeshift boxing palace, Darnell Jiles Jr. was throwing heat. So was his opponent.     Their gloves smacked. They bobbed and weaved, their thinly muscular b...
docs.lead_paragraph: The road to the dream this year was glazed with ice. But inside the Holiday Inn ballroom's makeshift boxing palace, Darnell Jiles Jr. was throwing heat. So was his opponent. Their gloves smacked. They bobbed and weaved, their thinly muscular bodies gliding about the ring swiftly as the crowd urged the fighters on. The bell sounded. And the winded warriors shuffled back to their corners for one final round of their semifinal fight on Friday.
docs.abstract: Article describes annual National Silver Gloves Tournament, amateur boxing competition for boys 10 to 15 years of age, in Olathe, Kansas; photos (M)

headline.main: Boxers as Young as 10 Begin Their Ring Cycle

docs.snippet: A red minivan had lurched east across Fifth Avenue into the shadow of St. Patrick's Cathedral, which was lighted by the moon and hundreds of lights directed by the police.    For a moment, it seemed as if the van would not stop. But it came to a h...
docs.lead_paragraph: A red minivan had lurched east across Fifth Avenue into the shadow of St. Patrick's Cathedral, which was lighted by the moon and hundreds of lights directed by the police. For a moment, it seemed as if the van would not stop. But it came to a halt in front of the raised hand of Police Officer Tell Beharry on Friday night.
docs.abstract: Vignettes of police activity at World Economic Forum in Manhattan (M)

docs.snippet: Ernest Pintoff, a filmmaker who won an Academy Award in 1963 for ''The Critic,'' a short animated satire about modern art, died Jan. 12 at a hospital in Woodland Hills, Calif. He was 70 and lived in Hollywood.    The cause was complications from a...
docs.lead_paragraph: Ernest Pintoff, a filmmaker who won an Academy Award in 1963 for ''The Critic,'' a short animated satire about modern art, died Jan. 12 at a hospital in Woodland Hills, Calif. He was 70 and lived in Hollywood. The cause was complications from a stroke, his family said.
docs.abstract: Ernest Pintoff, filmmaker who won oscar for short animated film, dies at age 70 (M)

headline.main: Ernest Pintoff, 70, Director Who Won an Oscar for Animated Film

docs.snippet: THE narrator of the Canadian film ''Maelström,'' which opened Jan. 25 in New York, is hard to get out of your head. That's because the narrator is a fish. Not your garden variety talking, or singing, mounted bass, but a bloody, prehistoric fish t...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE narrator of the Canadian film ''Maelström,'' which opened Jan. 25 in New York, is hard to get out of your head. That's because the narrator is a fish. Not your garden variety talking, or singing, mounted bass, but a bloody, prehistoric fish that tells its tale in a sort of last gasp as it's about to be beheaded by a fishmonger's cleaver. ''Some people who read the script even before the film was made had nightmares about the fish,'' chuckled Denis Villeneuve, the film's 34-year-old French-Canadian writer and director. And while he can't exactly explain why he chose an ancient (albeit animatronic) fish to narrate this otherwise very contemporary story set in Montreal, about a spoiled young woman whose life begins to unravel after a car accident, Mr. Villeneuve sees ''a link between telling a story and death.''
docs.abstract: Peter Kobel interviews Denis Villeneuve, Canadian who has written and directed new film Maelstrom, starring Marie-Josee Croze; photos (M)

headline.main: From a Canadian Filmmaker, a Tale Told by a Fish

docs.snippet: Elton John's new album, -- ''Songs From the West Coast,'' may not be topping the charts, but it seems to have spurred nostalgia in the fashion world for his sounds and style. The fashion photographer David LaChapelle directed Mr. John's latest vid...
docs.lead_paragraph: Elton John's new album, -- ''Songs From the West Coast,'' may not be topping the charts, but it seems to have spurred nostalgia in the fashion world for his sounds and style. The fashion photographer David LaChapelle directed Mr. John's latest video, ''This Train Don't Stop There Anymore,'' with Justin Timberlake of 'N Sync dressed as a retro Elton John. Mr. John will appear in the M.A.C. cosmetics Viva Glam ad campaign. Clothing styles are having an Elton moment: there's a revival of his Vegaslike fringe, studs and boldness, said Stacey Mayesh, the senior fashion editor at Marie Claire magazine. The eyewear company Facial Index fell under the sway of old-school Elton in creating a line of colorful, oversize sunglasses. Mr. John is to appear with 'N Sync on March 26 at a Saks Fifth Avenue and Cedars-Sinai benefit for women's cancer research, a yearly Los Angeles event attended by fashion-world insiders and post-Oscar stars. KAREN ROBINOVITZ
docs.abstract: Apparel and eyewear companies revive old-time Elton John clothing and accessory styles; photo (Pulse column) (S)
